A new episode of Echoes Through Time is out: "Marco Polo – Unveiling East and West: The Untold Impact of a Venetian Explorer."  

This week, I had one of those surreal (and, well, fictional) fireside chats with Marco Polo—whose journeys made my own sense of “adventure” (i.e., not getting lost in Venice) look a bit unimpressive. We explored what it meant to see the world’s largest cities when most of Europe was still thinking “big” meant a bustling fair; how paper money, coal, and cosmopolitan tolerance were not wild theories but living realities in Kublai Khan’s empire; and why Marco considered curiosity a greater inheritance than any spice-laden merchant ship. We touched on his run-ins with skepticism (Venetians gave him the nickname ‘Il Milione’ for a reason), his role as both observer and participant in a true global moment, and that odd feeling of coming home to find your world suddenly smaller—or just more precious.  

If you’re interested in how travel can fracture and then reconstruct your own map of reality (or just want to know why Marco Polo was both right and sometimes maybe... “embellishing”), I’d love for you to listen in.
